page1.title: Leave blank
page1.content:
Element1[type:TEXT][position:{l:5.54,t:0.54,w:26.1,h:1.53}][content:Overall user traffic and IoT traffic trends (Telecom & Unicom)][style:{size:;color:C00000}]
Element2[type:TEXT][position:{l:0.29,t:2.34,w:15.25,h:0.85}][content:Telecom overall traffic & handset daily-average traffic trends][style:{size:14.0;color:}]
Element3[type:TEXT][position:{l:0.34,t:10.81,w:15.25,h:0.85}][content:Unicom overall traffic & handset daily-average traffic trends][style:{size:14.0;color:}]
Element4[type:TEXT][position:{l:15.59,t:2.34,w:17.99,h:8.03}][content:Overall traffic trend: In Feb 2025, Telecom users’ overall daily-average traffic was *** TB lower than Unicom.
Telecom: Upward trend from Jan–Aug 2024, then gradual decline from Sep; Feb 2025 down 5.35% y/y; traffic peaked in Aug 2024.
Unicom: Upward trend from Jan–Dec 2024, gradual decline starting Jan 2025; Feb 2025 up 33.11% y/y; traffic peaked in Dec 2024.
Handset (non-IoT) traffic trend: In Feb 2025, Telecom’s handset daily-average traffic was 188 TB higher than Unicom.
Telecom: Rose from May–Aug 2024, then gradual decline from Sep; Feb 2025 is 18.1% lower vs May 2024.
Unicom: Stable from May–Nov 2024, gradual decline starting Dec; Feb 2025 is 9.83% lower vs May 2024.
IoT traffic trend: In Feb 2025, Telecom’s IoT daily-average traffic was *** TB lower than Unicom.
Telecom: Rose from May–Aug 2024, gradual decline from Sep, then slow rise in 2025; Feb 2025 is 34.69% higher vs May 2024.
Unicom: Downward from May–Aug 2024, rapid rise from Sep, slow decline in 2025; Feb 2025 is 33.06% higher vs May 2024.][style:{size:11.0,12.0;color:00B050,FF0000}]
Element5[type:TEXT][position:{l:1.34,t:18.28,w:14.19,h:0.68}][content:Note: Telecom IoT traffic data missing for Jan–Apr 2024.][style:{size:10.0;color:FF0000}]
Element6[type:TEXT][position:{l:15.59,t:10.81,w:17.99,h:7.09}][content:Telecom & Unicom — Commonalities:
Overall user traffic and handset traffic both show a downward trend; in Feb 2025 handset traffic is roughly flat across both.
Differences:
Telecom’s IoT traffic shows a downward trend with fluctuating share, recently rebounding.
Unicom’s IoT traffic and IoT share are both rising; IoT share reached 51% in Feb 2025.
Joint objective:
Both carriers should jointly strengthen throttling management for IoT SIMs.][style:{size:11.0;color:00B050,FF0000}]

page2.title: Leave blank
page2.content:
Element1[type:TEXT][position:{l:5.49,t:0.85,w:19.6,h:1.28}][content:IoT low-efficiency traffic SPID throttling plan — measures, effects, and issues][style:{size:24.0;color:C00000}]
Element2[type:TEXT][position:{l:1.27,t:2.33,w:15.48,h:0.85}][content:SPID-based throttling plan][style:{size:14.0;color:}]
Element3[type:TEXT][position:{l:1.26,t:11.83,w:15.49,h:1.67}][content:As of now, the province has completed the first batch of SPID throttling; >30,000 cells throttled; IoT traffic has dropped significantly; provincial 4G total traffic has peaked across all prefectures.][style:{size:12.0;color:FF0000}]
Element4[type:TEXT][position:{l:1.27,t:3.17,w:15.0,h:0.99}][content:Mechanism & policy][style:{size:13.0;color:}]
Element5[type:TEXT][position:{l:1.64,t:6.02,w:3.95,h:1.4}][content:Core side: bind IoT SIMs to specific SPIDs][style:{size:10.0;color:}]
Element6[type:TEXT][position:{l:6.73,t:6.02,w:4.52,h:1.4}][content:Radio side: configure throttling strategies for high-load cells][style:{size:10.0;color:}]
Element7[type:TEXT][position:{l:12.12,t:6.05,w:3.86,h:1.37}][content:Throttle based on PRB threshold configuration][style:{size:10.0;color:}]
Element8[type:TEXT][position:{l:1.27,t:7.48,w:15.31,h:1.86}][content:Selecting throttling cells:
Use SEQ to identify SPID=100 users; associate cells where SPID traffic concentrates with high-load cells to output target sectors.][style:{size:11.0,13.0;color:}]
Element9[type:TEXT][position:{l:1.79,t:9.39,w:2.92,h:1.12}][content:1) Identify SPID users][style:{size:10.0;color:}]
Element10[type:TEXT][position:{l:5.49,t:9.39,w:3.37,h:1.12}][content:2) Identify cells concentrating SPID user traffic][style:{size:10.0;color:}]
Element11[type:TEXT][position:{l:9.65,t:9.4,w:2.7,h:1.12}][content:3) Associate with high-load cells][style:{size:10.0;color:}]
Element12[type:TEXT][position:{l:13.29,t:9.4,w:2.82,h:1.12}][content:4) Output target throttling cells][style:{size:10.0;color:}]
Element13[type:TEXT][position:{l:1.33,t:10.96,w:15.41,h:0.85}][content:Effect of first-batch SPID throttling][style:{size:14.0;color:}]
Element14[type:TEXT][position:{l:1.27,t:13.84,w:3.66,h:1.54}][content:875 high-load cells relieved][style:{size:10.0;color:FF0000}]
Element15[type:TEXT][position:{l:12.84,t:13.87,w:3.74,h:1.54}][content:Busy-hour downlink PRB utilization −6.07%][style:{size:10.0;color:FF0000}]
Element16[type:TEXT][position:{l:9.0,t:13.87,w:3.84,h:1.54}][content:Busy-hour DL user experience rate +1.59 Mbps][style:{size:10.0;color:FF0000}]
Element17[type:TEXT][position:{l:1.17,t:4.15,w:15.58,h:1.79}][content:Bind a specific SPID to a certain user group; throttle SPID users on the radio side with three PRB-based thresholds at 5 Mbps, 3 Mbps, and 1 Mbps.][style:{size:12.0;color:}]
Element18[type:TEXT][position:{l:4.98,t:13.86,w:3.98,h:2.18}][content:Provincial adjusted-area SPID daily-average traffic −54.45 TB][style:{size:10.0;color:FF0000}]
Element19[type:TEXT][position:{l:17.82,t:2.33,w:14.84,h:0.85}][content:Next steps & pros/cons][style:{size:14.0;color:}]
Element20[type:TEXT][position:{l:17.82,t:11.01,w:14.65,h:0.85}][content:Current deployment progress; present bottlenecks & challenges][style:{size:14.0;color:}]
Element21[type:TEXT][position:{l:17.82,t:3.35,w:7.0,h:0.75}][content:Normalize SPID-based throttling rollout][style:{size:10.0;color:}]
Element22[type:TEXT][position:{l:25.46,t:3.35,w:7.0,h:0.75}][content:Advance jointly with Unicom][style:{size:10.0;color:}]
Element23[type:TEXT][position:{l:17.82,t:4.12,w:7.0,h:6.78}][content:Advantages
No cap on number of throttled users; relies on group subscription info ID configuration for IoT SIMs.
Flexible throttling policies based on cell load.
Disadvantages
Depends on group configuration; potential gaps in high-traffic configuration.
Provincial MME needs subscription info ID; related features require separate procurement.][style:{size:11.0;color:00B050,FF0000}]
Element24[type:TEXT][position:{l:25.46,t:4.12,w:7.0,h:6.73}][content:Progress
Unicom IoT traffic share >50% in Hebei.
In Jan, Unicom’s provincial MME configured partial subscription info IDs by number segment, aligned with Telecom.
Plan
CT/CU exchange SPID throttling details and respectively configure throttling policies.][style:{size:11.0;color:00B050,FF0000}]
Element25[type:TEXT][position:{l:17.9,t:11.83,w:14.84,h:3.33}][content:Latest progress
Monthly: output a full list of cells with SPID=100 traffic share to cities for throttling; lists of cells with high load & share >20%, and non-high load & share >50% will be exchanged between CT/CU for processing.][style:{size:12.0;color:}]
Element26[type:TEXT][position:{l:17.9,t:15.19,w:14.84,h:4.61}][content:Bottlenecks & challenges
Nokia’s IoT SIM throttling requires a license; currently not available on the live network—needs vendor purchase.
SPID tagging coverage in-network remains low; recent IoT traffic shows rebound. Recommend the IoT company expand SPID tagging scope.][style:{size:12.0;color:}]

page3.title: Leave blank
page3.content:
Element1[type:TEXT][position:{l:1.27,t:2.33,w:15.48,h:0.85}][content:CT/CU 4G shutdown & decommissioning status][style:{size:14.0;color:}]
Element2[type:TEXT][position:{l:1.27,t:3.18,w:15.48,h:3.24}][content:Shutdown/decommissioning assessment
CT/CU jointly conduct 4G network thinning under the principles of “quality assurance and cost reduction”. After multiple rounds of discussion, mid-band 4G thinning proceeds in two phases; Telecom estimated *** full-site decommissions; Unicom estimated 328.][style:{size:12.0;color:FF0000}]
Element3[type:TABLE[0,0]][position:{l:1.44,t:14.87,w:6.95,h:0.73}][content:Reason category][style:{size:11.0;color:FFFFFF}]
Element4[type:TABLE[0,1]][position:{l:8.39,t:14.87,w:3.06,h:0.73}][content:Site count][style:{size:11.0;color:FFFFFF}]
Element5[type:TABLE[0,2]][position:{l:11.45,t:14.87,w:5.3,h:0.73}][content:Share][style:{size:11.0;color:FFFFFF}]
Element6[type:TABLE[1,0]][position:{l:1.44,t:15.6,w:6.95,h:0.99}][content:Co-sited with 5G & low-band LTE][style:{size:11.0;color:000000}]
Element7[type:TABLE[1,2]][position:{l:11.45,t:15.6,w:5.3,h:0.99}][content:68.23%][style:{size:11.0;color:000000}]
Element8[type:TABLE[2,0]][position:{l:1.44,t:16.59,w:6.95,h:0.99}][content:High load][style:{size:11.0;color:000000}]
Element9[type:TABLE[2,2]][position:{l:11.45,t:16.59,w:5.3,h:0.99}][content:29.30%][style:{size:11.0;color:000000}]
Element10[type:TABLE[3,0]][position:{l:1.44,t:17.57,w:6.95,h:0.99}][content:High-speed rail scenario][style:{size:11.0;color:000000}]
Element11[type:TABLE[3,2]][position:{l:11.45,t:17.57,w:5.3,h:0.99}][content:2.47%][style:{size:11.0;color:000000}]
Element12[type:TEXT][position:{l:17.26,t:2.33,w:15.48,h:0.85}][content:Impact of IoT on shutdown/decommissioning][style:{size:14.0;color:}]
Element13[type:TEXT][position:{l:1.45,t:12.3,w:15.61,h:2.57}][content:Reasons why full-site shutdown/decommissioning is not feasible
Among near-by sites for user experience assurance, the following special cases will not be thinned: co-sited with 5G mid-band & 4G low-band, high-speed rail scenarios, and high-load sites; high-load accounts for 29.30%.][style:{size:;color:FF0000}]
Element14[type:TEXT][position:{l:17.26,t:3.16,w:16.21,h:3.24}][content:Impact of different IoT traffic shares on shutdown/decommissioning
*** high-load sites involve 4,604 high-load cells. For associated cells, IoT traffic share ≥20% is the key factor for high-load designation; 3,193 high-load cells (>69.35%) have IoT share ≥20%.][style:{size:12.0;color:}]
Element15[type:TEXT][position:{l:22.67,t:13.93,w:10.81,h:4.41}][content:IoT-driven: all high-load cells under the site have IoT traffic share >20%.
Non-IoT-driven: all high-load cells under the site have IoT traffic share ≤20%.
Mixed IoT & non-IoT factors: under the site, some high-load cells have IoT share ≤20% and some >20%.][style:{size:11.0;color:000000}]
Element16[type:TEXT][position:{l:5.54,t:0.54,w:26.1,h:1.81}][content:Impact of IoT traffic on provincial CT/CU 4G shutdown/decommissioning][style:{size:;color:C00000}]
Element17[type:TEXT][position:{l:17.26,t:10.69,w:15.61,h:3.24}][content:Classification of high-load sites impacted by IoT
4,604 high-load cells belong to 2,699 sites; IoT-impacted high-load sites: ***; non-IoT-impacted high-load sites: 701; mixed-factor high-load sites: 398.][style:{size:12.0;color:000000,FF0000}]

page5.title: Leave blank
page5.content:
Element1[type:TEXT][position:{l:5.54,t:0.54,w:26.1,h:1.81}][content:5G traffic uplift status][style:{size:;color:C00000}]
Element2[type:TEXT][position:{l:0.38,t:10.4,w:16.52,h:0.85}][content:High backflow cell count and proportion trend][style:{size:14.0;color:}]
Element3[type:TEXT][position:{l:0.38,t:2.36,w:16.52,h:0.86}][content:5G traffic, offload ratio, and residence ratio trends][style:{size:14.0;color:}]
Element4[type:TEXT][position:{l:16.97,t:2.36,w:16.3,h:0.85}][content:Key actions for 5G traffic uplift][style:{size:14.0;color:}]
Element5[type:TEXT][position:{l:16.97,t:3.36,w:16.28,h:9.49}][content:5G traffic uplift
Accelerate projects 5081 and 5802; complete NR800M launch across 89 counties; add 32,000 NR800M sectors to expand 5G coverage area by 40%.
High backflow rectification
Speed up 5G build-out; 5G cell count reaches 225,000, up 28.65% y/y.
Improve 5G coverage; 5G MR coverage rate 98.56%, +2.53 pp y/y; OTT 5G composite coverage ranks #3 nationwide, maintaining a lead.
Fix “4G-only (no 5G)” cells; proportion down 47.6%.
Tune inter-RAT parameters; 4→5 inter-RAT parameter compliance 98.52%.
Resolve all cases of overly high 5→4 thresholds.
Strengthen O&M; optimize 9,170 zero-traffic 5G cells; zero-traffic 5G cell share 1.30%, −4.99 pp y/y.][style:{size:12.0;color:}]
